content: I really need more small-town scatter
hey guys welcome back to black magic
crafts now that my gaming has become more evenly split between playing
tabletop RPGs and playing skirmish games my terrain needs have slightly changed
when playing Dungeons and Dragons I did from time to time set up elaborate
outdoor town scenarios and encounters but not nearly as often as things in the
dungeon or on tiles but now that I'm playing Frost grave quite a bit and you
know looking into other skirmish games outdoor cityscapes are becoming much
more important and I'm finding that my limited supply it's kind of comical that
I think my supply of terrain is limited it's pretty decent but still I'm finding
it limiting when trying to do different tabletop setups for a town each week and
I've come to realize especially for a game like Frost grave where you want
tons of little line of site blocking bits and stuff that it's the little
features that really make the table more interesting and dynamic buildings are
awesome but it's the little features like the statues and the wells and the
bushes so I found myself needing more of that and when I was brainstorming what
types of little things I could build I thought a bulletin board or town notice
board this is kind of a classic project and it's something I've seen a lot of
crafters make and I've kind of always thought yeah it's not really that
important to build for D&D while adventurers do often start around a
notice board that's more of a narrative thing I have yet to ever run a combat
encounter surrounding one of them but when it came to just wanting little
elements to decorate a table for a skirmish game it was the perfect item
it's small fun to build blocks line-of-sight and if I ever do want to
use it in D&D well now
have it so I set to work and I built a little bulletin board turned out pretty
good let's take a look at how I built it
this build started with some medium weight chipboard in order to get a good
size for the actual board portion of the piece I used everybody's favorite mini
sir for scale this is a perfect example of making something using a miniature as
a guide rather than any sort of measurement or conversion table it just
needs to look right when used with whatever scale minis you use in your
games I wanted this board to look as though the average human would be at a
comfortable eye level viewing it and able to plausibly reach the upper
portion of the board to hang posters once I had the board cut out I traced
out a bit of a border this would be the areas that I wanted to cover with the
timber framing and adding these lines would help me keep things even when
applying them I didn't measure these out or use a ruler to draw the lines I just
eyeballed them and finger gauge the lines finger gauging a straight line on
a piece is possibly the most useful skill I picked up in my years as a
carpenter and it's something I recommend builders of any vocation practice and
perfect using my procs on hot wire cutter i milled up some timber pieces
out of XPS foam again the width of these were not measured but rather I balled to
a size that I thought seemed appropriate using a brass wire brush I added wood
grain texture to the foam my idea was to cut a groove on one edge of the foam
pieces that the chipboard could slide into this proved to be more difficult
than I had anticipated but I did manage to get the pieces glued in place crap
after breaking my first pair of legs on this thing I started over again this
time before placing any pressure on the foam I inserted toothpicks into the
length of the foam to add some strength to the piece this is crucial when doing
a build that has long narrow pieces of foam supporting a
larger portion of the build once my frame was complete I ripped some
very thin strips of XPS foam that would act as the planks on the main board I
used the same technique here that I did on my Geysers in chains build I really
like this method because it adds a lot of variation to the foam planks making
them look a lot more believable originally I had planned for this to
just be a board but I thought it would make more sense if there was at least
some little overhanging roof to protect the posters I cut a narrow strip of
chipboard and hot glued it to the top timber at a slight angle I then placed
some toothpicks beneath it to act as diagonal bracing for the roof using the
same method of making wood shingles that I outlined in my video dedicated to
shingles check the card at the top of the screen if you want to check out that
video I proceeded to lay down a few rows of shingles it actually seems to be
harder to do this on small pieces than it is on a larger one because there's no
time for the glue to set up and things want to move around so if doing this
again I'd probably opt for hot glue instead of PVA in order to finish the
top of the roof I added some wider planks to act as caps at this point I
thought the toothpick bracing looked pretty stupid so I swapped them out for
some beefier looking foam pieces I also added some fascia boards to the sides of
the roof to hide the layers of shingles and chipboard now for the base it would
have been wise to go through the effort of making up something out of thin MDF
but I really wasn't feeling up for leaving the game room so I opted for the
lazy method of just using a tongue depressor this was a mistake
I tried to carve up the wood to give it more of an organic shape but really I
just ended up making it less stable I drilled some holes in the wood stick for
the little bits of toothpick that I had left proud of the bulletin board frame
to slide into this would make a pretty strong connection using a rotary tool i
sanded down the excess toothpicks to be flush with
the bottom of the tongue depressor this all worked fine
until I tried to stand the thing up I needed a wider base to offset the
top-heavy piece again I was too lazy to go and make something out of MDF so I
cut out a shape from some chipboard and hot glued the wood base right to that to
make it look like this thing was standing in a mound of muddy earth I
mixed up some sculpt a mold and covered the base in my head I thought this would
also add some good weight to the piece without any warping taking place
surely the wood stick and the minimally shrinking sculpting mold would be stable
enough to not cause any warping this thought process was also a mistake and I
would discover that later to create some more paintable elements to the base I
used some PVA glue and construction sand to add some rocks to the scene once that
had all mostly dried I gave everything a coat in my black magic base coat which
is of course a combination of black craft paint and matte Mod Podge after it
had all dried I admitted fault and defeat in regards to the base it had
cupped significantly more than I would have thought possible given the shape
and size but it did and it was wobbly and annoying an easy way to fix this
post problem is to put a bunch of hot glue on the bottom of the piece then
press it down onto some parchment paper on a flat surface this will cause the
hot glue to fill any uneven spots and once cooled provide a base that sits
nice and flat on the table this is not an elegant solution but it works once
it's too late to make the base properly I painted the wood using my usual method
and if you want to see a more detailed guide to painting something like this
check out last week's episode where I painted and weathered my tiny Tudor
house build I used my same homemade moss recipe that I demonstrated in that Tudor
house building to make this thing look old and decrepit
if your game setting is not as dark and
miserable as mine seems to be then maybe you want to skip the step and make the
piece look to be in better repair because this piece was so simple I
thought it really needed more interesting things going on in the base
so I added a variety of static grass Tufts and flowers to the base to make it
look more interesting I really like these little white flowers as they work
great for wild flowers or flowering weeds now for the posters I was
originally gonna make my own but I remembered that some members of the
tabletop crafters guild Facebook group had actually uploaded some to the file
section of the group I dug through pages and pages of files and found three
different uploads that I'll link in the video description below
I found that I needed to print each of these at 50% scale to be appropriately
sized for this piece and for 28 millimeter minis to print these I only
used my cheap black and white laser printer so the quality was not very good
and well it looked like it was printed by a computer if you don't have a good
quality printer it may be worth going to a print shop to do these especially the
file that was already colored in a variety of aged parchment colors to try
and hide the computer printed look I weathered the paper using washes made
from acrylic inks I absolutely went overboard here I was really trying to
hide the pixelated printing but in the end just made the posters look far too
dark and too red and I would not go to this extreme if I were to do it over
again attaching these to the board I tried a variety of methods of applying
the glue some worked better than others but in the end I found the least
annoying method to be painting on some watered-down PVA right onto the board
then dropping the paper into it and painting on another layer of water damn
glue my favorite detail in this piece was the very last ones that I added
which were too crumpled up posters on the ground I wanted it to look like they
had fallen off and been blown into the weeds little details like this can
really elevate a mediocre looking piece into the territory of a pretty
good-looking piece overall I'm really happy with this build
it will be great scatter and in general it's just a fun little element on a
table my only regret is not getting the posters printed at a higher quality I
think I should get a large sheet of these posters printed professionally
just to have them on hand to add to various projects and buildings in the
future if you want to try this build for yourself or you want to stock up on
supplies tools whatever head over to Blackmagic craft CA there I have my
essential equipment store with info and links to all of the tools and supplies
that I regularly use purchasing through these links costs you nothing extra but
because they are Amazon affiliate links I earn a small Commission that helps
fund the production of videos like this one another great way you can help fund
these videos is by supporting black magic crafts on patreon if you really
enjoy my videos and you've gotten a lot of value out of them supporting me there
is a great way to say thanks and to help me continue making them to hopefully
inspire and help even more people get into this really wonderful hobby that's
it that's all a little fun project complete and something that is gonna be
a really neat addition to my collection of town stuff this is a great project if
you just want to dip your toes into some of the techniques used on bigger
buildings like my Tudor house it's a lot of the same stuff just less of it so
it's a great place to practice things like wood weathering and moss and all
that other fun stuff before jumping into a bigger project again I will put links
to the poster files in the video description below they're in a private
Facebook group the table tabletop crafters guild so you probably have to
be a member to access them and I mean if you're not a member already well you
should be it's a great great place and thank you to the members that way back
in the day posted those files there it saved me a lot of time I didn't have to
go out searching for images make my own so I hope you guys enjoyed
this video I hope you found it informative and inspiring if you liked
it hit that like button let me know in the comments section below that's it for
this week guys Cheers hope you have a great weekend see you next week
